reviewText:
In this game you play as the goddess Athena, who's job it is to guide Odysseus' boats to safety. You do this by altering the wind strength, which always blows toward their destination, and by dragging your mouse through the sea to create currents.

This sounds simple enough, but you also have to prevent the ships from hitting rocks and sand bars, and avoiding other dangers like a cyclops throwing rocks at them (you can catch the rocks by clicking on them with the mouse). Additionally you need to direct the boats to statues to unlock gates and there are also bonuses to pick up along the way. Naturally it gets harder as you progress, with newer dangers and more difficult maps to negotiate.

Although the graphics are pleasing, the resolution is only 640x480. You have a choice of full screen or windowed.

To be honest, it's not my type of game and it didn't hold my interest for very long, but it's by no means a bad game. It wouldn't appeal to everyone, but it's fairly challenging and I'm sure some gamers would enjoy it.

Conclusion: a decent casual game ideal for a quick play when you don't have much time to spare.

reviewText:
Relaxing & clever // Recommended for casual gamers
~Full Disclosure: This game was reviewed with a key given by the developers~
+ Interesting & neat historical/mythological back-story
+ Simple mechanics made challenging through the necessary balance of obstacle avoidance & wind/current management
+ Food offerings offer opportunities for bonus points
+ Though the visuals are underwhelming, to say the least, everything is crisp & responsive in practice
+ Some basic puzzle elements (i.e., beacon switches)

- No resolution options (default resolution in windowed mode is entirely too small, & fullscreen is not an option if one is using more than one monitor)
- Feels overwhelmingly like a touchscreen tablet port, though it still manages to be functional & enjoyable
- Limited replayability beyond a drive for higher scores

reviewText: God Game is a casual puzzle game inspired by The Odyssey" (you know that famous old greek myth!). Your goal is  a simple yet getting progressively more difficult one: Get your ships safely to the exit by manipulating wind/air currents. To finish a level you have to have saved a certain number of ships; stretch goals include an expert rating (save more ships) and a perfect rating (save all ships). While it is pretty easy at first to get perfect rating
date: pretty soon the difficulty steps up by introducing environmental hazards like sand banks
recommended: reefs and even enemies e.g. Cyclops
hoursPlayed: Harpies (the later can even be used to your advantage and you will have to utilize them at times).\nThe game itself is nice to play in between or to relax. My only gripe is the lack of incentive to go back to levels and try harder at getting expert/perfect rating...achievements would definitely do the trick here."

reviewText:
This game is really fun, it's simple and the first couple levels are perfect for getting the hang of the game.
Mechanics are solid; boats will sail directly towards the exit (although be careful if there is a reef/sandbar in the way) when you start up the wind, you can use currents to help guide a boat or two at a time - which is useful for some of the levels to open gates/locks.

Music is a plus, personally I prefer the in-game music although there is an option to disable it as well if you prefer.

To complete a level there are several conditions:

The first is a minimum amount of boats you need to get to the exit of the level, usually simple although on higher levels it can be a challenge!

The second victory condition is if you get a higher number (depends on the level) of boats than the minimum.

While the graphics are not amazing or anything like that they look well done and fit the tone (early greek ages) of the game, I can easily run and play this game on my laptop as well which is always a plus.

Over all I definitly recommend this game if you are a fan of puzzle games, four out of five stars!


Cheers,

SHARKE BYTE

reviewText:
A short game, with a mix of both action and puzzle elements.

A very interesting concept, using mouse gestures to guide boats toward the goal. Water currents develop depending on your actions, so you must plan your use of wind carefully.

While this is a novel idea, it does unfortunately have some major design issues which cannot be overlooked. These include the repetitive, limited set of sounds which can often overlap; but also means playing this game at a very low resolution with no option to alter it.

With lots of fun ways to interact with the environment, you may find new mechanics that will surprise you. This game will test your multitasking skills, but this game can quickly become frustrating and tedious. While I support the efforts that the developers have gone to, this feels more like a demo of a game that one might be found on an old floppy disk.


Note: I was gifted this game for the purpose of me giving review.

reviewText:
As my first '♥♥♥♥ it, it's 20p game', this was a disaster. I thought that nothing could go wrong with a 20p investment. I was wrong, oh so wrong.

The game is structured around you getting boats from point A to point B, e.g. you start with 40 boats and have to get 10 to the exit. This idea is so flawed, firstly due to the fact that you may as well kill the boats yourself if you want them to get anywhere since they often get stuck in annoying places, making you want to commit genocide in order to get to the next mission 30 seconds early. The main score is pretty ♥♥♥♥, exemplified by the fact that it's the only song you’ll hear.

My favourite thing about this is probably the fact the water looks hypnotically psychadelic to the point where I just ♥♥♥♥ about with water and don’t really do anything with the boats.

Perhaps this game is actually a complex metaphor about the mundanity of life as a Greek; with which your worshiping results in your impending doom and failure as a human beings. It's probably just ♥♥♥♥ though.

reviewText:
If Greek Mythology has taught me one thing, it's never tick off a God. After the fall of Troy the Greek fleet, lead by Odysseus (AKA Ulysses), set sail for home. But Posiden is not happy and, as Gods tend to do, decides to destroy the mighty fleet.

That's where you come into play. You play as the hand of the Goddess Athena, determined to save the ships and sailors from their watery grave.

In this Lemmings-inspired puzzle games lets you take indirect action to save as many greek ships as possible. You'll create gusts of wind, alter water currents, swat harpies from the sky, lasso tornados, catch falling boulders and more... You know, typical god stuff.

Recommended if you enjoy a fast paced casual.
voteText: 7 of 13 people (54%) found this review helpful

reviewText: I was surprised at how much I enjoyed this game.  It has simple mechanics that are easy to learn along with clear instructions on how to use them.  The focus of the game is straightforward: get your boats from point A to point B.  But therein lies the challenge! Cyclops throwing rocks, twirling whirlwinds, beachy sandbars and rocky cliffs provide entertaining and difficult challenges, yet its not too hard where I feel overwhelmed and want to give up.  And I didn't even make it to the more unique obstacles like sea-monsters, harpies and sirens.  Nevertheless, I was engrossed in the game.  Very fun, casual strategy game that anyone can play with just a mouse.

reviewText:
Fun little puzzle game.  You play god by controlling the oceans and wind and other things.  Its really easy to grasp the concept but it can be really tough at some levels.

I have only played the first handful of levels at the time of this review, so keep that in mind:  You are given a set amount of boats that you have to get from point A to point B, there are obstacles and some objectives.  Say you have 20 boats, you can pass the level by getting 5 boats to the objective without being destroyed, or you can pass the level with EXPERT by getting 15 boats to the end.

Definitely a cool concept and I would recommend it as an interesting puzzle/RTS.  Very different from anything I have ever played so thats a +1

reviewText:
After 12 levels, I'd say God Game: The Odyssey is a surprisingly fun little game. The player can use wind and water currents to guide a herd of ships to their destinations while avoiding various perils, Due to the force of the elements, the ships are very hard to steer in an exact manner, so the player can only be successful if he thinks a bit forward and plans sweeping fleet movements ahead. Good multitasking is also an advantage as many of the perils can be negated by divine (ie. player) intervention, but leave the ships to their own devices for more than a couple of seconds, and they're bound to stray into their destruction.
All the levels so far had adequate solutions - sometimes you can get away with being a bit clumsy if you're lucky, but luck is not required.
God Game: The Odyssey is simple but fun, quality entertainment for a few hours. It's worth your money even at the full 2.5EUR price.

reviewText: Do you like puzzles? and mazes? that take a little more to think about, while enjoying  a ''sparknotes'' story of the greatest story ever ? Homers epic of the return travel of King Odysseus of Ithica to his home-island, after the great Trojan war, is told in short little paragraphs while you play '' missions/levels '' of controlling the wind and water currents as the goddess Athena, to guide Odysseus's fleet of ships back home. Using these powers as the goddess Athena you change water and wind currents for Odysseus, you help his fleet over come rocks, sandbars, cyclopes,cyclones, harpies, lotus flowers and other crazy obstacles. The gameplay is easy, fun and music is a catchy greek thing (that if needed can be turned off for concentration).  A good introduction to a good story and hope you get through the levels to finish it!.

reviewText: In addition to being a Goddess, I like the game because it's fun and challening.  The fluid dynamic is amazing.  The game is very easy to learn, but it's hard to help the ships sometimes as they won't move as you wish sometimes due to unanticipated movement of the water.  For example, when you create current in one direction it may bounce off the shore and create an eddy or counter current.  Over all it's a fun and engaging game.

reviewText: This is actually a pretty cool little game.  You are a Greek God and need to control the air and water (so far) and move your fleet safetly through from point A to B through obstacles.  Although I haven't played it in length,  for the price point - it's definately worth the buy.  I'll play it again later for sure.!

reviewText:
The game looks like it's from the 90's but it's a funny new puzzel game. You move the boats from point A to B using Wind and the Current of the Water to move them along. The Mechanics and physics of the game is very well done. You'll have reef/sandbar in the way that you'll need to move around. So controlling a few ships at a time helps.

Now I can see how the early settlers felt like in the Ocean. Like the God's were F*cking with them.

Would love to see some achievements for the game.
